Week 1 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Functions

  • Inverses

Symbols

Here are a bunch of symbols that you'll probably see during lecture (and if you're a math major, for the rest of your life).

Definition
  • R= the set of real numbers =(−∞,∞)\mathbb{R} = \text{ the set of real numbers } = \p{-\infty, \infty}R= the set of real numbers =(−∞,∞)
  • ∈ =\in\: =∈= "is in" or "is an element of"
  • ∃ =\exists\: =∃= "there exists"
  • ∀ =\forall\: =∀= "for all" or "for any" or "for every"
  •   ⟹   =\implies\: =⟹= "implies"
Example 1.

∃\exists∃ water ∈\in∈ my fridge

∀\forall∀ student ∈\in∈ MATH 31B, the student is an undergraduate

you are here   ⟹  \implies⟹ you ∈\in∈ MATH 31B

you are here   ̸ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣  ⟹  \ \ \not\!\!\!\implies  ⟹ you are awake

Set Notation

You're probably familiar with intervals to specify sets (e.g., (a,b)\p{a, b}(a,b), [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b], etc.). While these are useful, some sets may be hard or tedious to write as intervals, so we're going to introduce a new, more general way to specify sets.

Example 2.

{x∈R∣x≠0}=(−∞,0)∪(0,∞)=R∖{0}\set{x \in \R \mid x \neq 0} = \p{-\infty, 0} \cup \p{0, \infty} = \mathbb{R} \setminus \set{0}{x∈R∣x=0}=(−∞,0)∪(0,∞)=R∖{0}
Example 3.

The domain of f(x)=tan⁡xf\p{x} = \tan{x}f(x)=tanx is {x∈R∣x≠π2+πn, n is an integer}\set{x \in \R \mid x \neq \frac{\pi}{2} + \pi n,\ n \text{ is an integer}}{x∈R∣x=2π​+πn, n is an integer}.
Exercise 1.

Write {x∈R∣a<x and x≤b}\set{x \in \R \mid a < x \text{ and } x \leq b}{x∈R∣a<x and x≤b} as an interval.
Exercise 2.

Write the domain of f(x)=cot⁡xf\p{x} = \cot{x}f(x)=cotx using this notation.

Functions

A function fff always comains with a domain DDD, and the range of fff is determined by DDD. If the domain isn't specified, then it's usually taken to be the largest set where fff is defined.

Example 4.

If f(x)=1xf\p{x} = \frac{1}{x}f(x)=x1​ and DDD is not specified, then we assume D={x∈R∣x≠0}D = \set{x \in \R \mid x \neq 0}D={x∈R∣x=0}.
Example 5.

Let f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2.

  • D=R  ⟹  R=[0,∞)D = \R \implies R = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=R⟹R=[0,∞)

  • D=[0,∞)  ⟹  R=[0,∞)D = \left[ 0, \infty \right) \implies R = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=[0,∞)⟹R=[0,∞)

  • D={x∈R∣x>2}  ⟹  R=(4,∞)D = \set{x \in \R \mid x > 2} \implies R = \p{4, \infty}D={x∈R∣x>2}⟹R=(4,∞)

Inverses

What is an Inverse?

Given a function fff, we'd like to know if we can go "backwards" from fff. This is useful if you need to solve something like f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y; if we can "undo" fff, then we automatically have the solution to the equation. This can be done if fff is invertible:

Definition

Let fff have domain DDD and range RRR. If ∃g\exists g∃g with domain RRR and range DDD such that

  • f(g(x))=x∀x∈Rf\p{g\p{x}} = x\quad\forall x \in Rf(g(x))=x∀x∈R and
  • g(f(x))=x∀x∈Dg\p{f\p{x}} = x\quad\forall x \in Dg(f(x))=x∀x∈D,

then we say fff is invertible and we call f−1=gf^{-1} = gf−1=g the inverse of fff.

When is there an Inverse?

So when does fff have an inverse? Let's look at a situation where fff does not have one.

fff doesn't have an inverse here because we can't go backwards from yyy to get both aaa and bbb. Indeed, any function ggg with domain RRR will map yyy to either aaa or bbb, but not both. The problem is that fff maps two different elements to the same thing, so if we prevent this, fff will have an inverse.

To prevent this, we need fff to map two different elements to two different things. More succinctly, a≠b  ⟹  f(a)≠f(b)a \neq b \implies f\p{a} \neq f\p{b}a=b⟹f(a)=f(b). If fff satisfies this, then we call fff one-to-one, but this isn't the only way to tell if fff is one-to-one:

Definition (one-to-one)

Let fff have domain DDD, and suppose one of the following is true about fff:

  • a≠b  ⟹  f(a)≠f(b) ∀a,b∈Da \neq b \implies f\p{a} \neq f\p{b}\ \forall a, b \in Da=b⟹f(a)=f(b) ∀a,b∈D or
  • f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y has exactly one solution ∀y∈R\forall y \in R∀y∈R or
  • f(a)=f(b)  ⟹  a=b ∀a,b∈Df\p{a} = f\p{b} \implies a = b\ \forall a, b \in Df(a)=f(b)⟹a=b ∀a,b∈D or
  • fff passes the horizontal line test.

Then we say fff is one-to-one or injective.

Notice that the domain is very important when determining whether fff is one-to-one or not.

Example 6.

Let f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2.

  • If D=RD = \RD=R, then fff is not one-to-one.

    f(x)=1f\p{x} = 1f(x)=1 has two solutions: −1-1−1 and 111.

  • If D=[0,∞)D = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=[0,∞), then fff is one-to-one.

    Since fff is one-to-one, it has an inverse, which is f−1(x)=xf^{-1}\p{x} = \sqrt{x}f−1(x)=x​.
